Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the power of the appointed board under Obamacare, suggesting that it will have the ability to come between patients and their doctors in determining treatment options.
Lack enough support: The claim does not provide sufficient evidence or support for the assertion that the appointed board will have such power.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the appointed board will interfere in the doctor-patient relationship, without providing evidence to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert's verdict provides an alternative explanation by stating that the board's focus is on cost-savings and not micro-managing patient care, and that Congress has the power to overrule the board's recommendations.
